function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Increased connectivity of urban green areas may lead to higher tick populations, increasing the risk of tick-borne infections in humans.","Impact":"Higher risk of human infections with tick-borne pathogens, potentially leading to illnesses such as Lyme disease.","Mitigation":"Implementing preventive measures such as awareness campaigns, guidance on avoiding tick attacks, and proper tick removal methods. Additionally, targeted solutions to decrease the number of infected small mammals in the environment.","Technologies":"Awareness campaigns, guidance materials, targeted pest control solutions.","People":"Residents and visitors of urban green areas, especially those who frequent outdoor spaces with vegetation.","Owner":"Local municipalities, public health organizations, and urban planning authorities."},{"Description":"Use of chemical sprays and applications for tick control threatens harmless non-target species and provides only temporary results.","Impact":"Harm to non-target species and temporary effectiveness of tick control measures.","Mitigation":"Exploring alternative methods of tick control that are less harmful to non-target species and provide more sustainable results.","Technologies":"Environmentally friendly tick control methods, such as targeted pest control solutions and natural predators of ticks.","People":"Environmental agencies, pest control organizations, and researchers in the field of tick-borne diseases.","Owner":"Environmental agencies, pest control organizations."},{"Description":"Inconsistent effectiveness of tick control methods in different ecological contexts, as demonstrated by the differing results of pyrethrin-soaked cotton fibers in different geographic locations.","Impact":"Inability to rely on a one-size-fits-all approach to tick control, leading to challenges in implementing effective control measures.","Mitigation":"Conducting detailed ecological assessments to tailor tick control methods to specific geographic locations and ecological contexts. Research and development of location-specific tick control strategies.","Technologies":"Ecological assessments, geographic information systems, and location-specific pest control solutions.","People":"Ecologists, entomologists, and researchers in the field of tick-borne diseases.","Owner":"Research institutions, public health organizations, and environmental agencies."}]}
